answers.author: Josephine Valencia
answers.text:
Out of curiosity, I placed your question in Google Translate for Spanish.  This is the English equivalent of how the translation read:  “ Is there someone sideways of Google Translate on your website ( to offer contents in Spanish, etc) -or any other service that is better (for example, babblefish)?  What results have you seen?  Not translatable and cons?   Other focus or comments you want to share?  Thank you.”   
I would not recommend this or any other automatic translation programs for websites.  But I will admit, this translation is better than I anticipated and much better than the paid “Browse Aloud” service that my previous employer used.   Browse Aloud is mainly used for accessibility features, but does have a translation component.  
If you are determined to offer a translation option, you will need to change your style of writing in English to be most effective.   While in English, most readers interpret “vague” words from context.  Spanish is a more verbose language and usually has specific words with different meanings while English may just have one word for multiple meanings.    For example, the English word trailer could refer to a movie, caravan, home, vehicle, trash container, etc.   Each of those different meaning, has a specific and different translations in Spanish.  An automatic translator will sometimes pick the wrong word.
